records.text: I use a few apps from #Flatpak that are pretty good (Apostrophe and Krita my beloveds). But there are a few things that I still feel counter to what a more "global" method of distributing apps for Linux should be, and why when it comes to "global" I search for AppImages where I can.One is hardware layer compatibility. I like videogames a lot but most if not all gaming stuff I have seen on Flatpak, Steam and Retroarch included, don't pick up my audio setup. Flatpak seems hard-coded to require the crap called "Pulseaudio", and ignores my legit #ALSA setup, which partly exists due to a hardware bug in my machine's motherboard that only ALSA and maybe #Pipewire check for that I know.I can't change the motherboard's audio chip's microtransistors. I *can*, however, use AppImage instead of Flatpak because ALSA Just Works.I trust and hope Pipewire won't cause me such issues once I eventually migrate to a newer machine. Or I can keep ALSA. And hope that Flatpak becomes more hardware-layer agnostic.

records.text: I use a few apps from #Flatpak that are pretty good (Apostrophe and Krita my beloveds). But there are a few things that I still feel counter to what a more "global" method of distributing apps for Linux should be, and why when it comes to "global" I search for AppImages where I can.One is hardware layer compatibility. I like videogames a lot but most if not all gaming stuff I have seen on Flatpak, Steam and Retroarch included, don't pick up my audio setup. Flatpak seems hard-coded to require the crap called "Pulseaudio", and ignores my legit #ALSA setup, which partly exists due to a hardware bug in my machine's motherboard that only ALSA and maybe #Pipewire check for that I know.I can't change the motherboard's audio chip's microtransistors. I *can*, however, use AppImage instead of Flatpak because ALSA Just Works.I trust and hope Pipewire won't cause me such issues once I eventually migrate to a newer machine. Or I can keep ALSA. And hope that Flatpak becomes more hardware-layer agnostic.

records.text: I use a few apps from #Flatpak that are pretty good (Apostrophe and Krita my beloveds). But there are a few things that I still feel counter to what a more "global" method of distributing apps for Linux should be, and why when it comes to "global" I search for AppImages where I can.One is hardware layer compatibility. I like videogames a lot but most if not all gaming stuff I have seen on Flatpak, Steam and Retroarch included, don't pick up my audio setup. Flatpak seems hard-coded to require the crap called "Pulseaudio", and ignores my legit #ALSA setup, which partly exists due to a hardware bug in my machine's motherboard that only ALSA and maybe #Pipewire check for that I know.I can't change the motherboard's audio chip's microtransistors. I *can*, however, use AppImage instead of Flatpak because ALSA Just Works.I trust and hope Pipewire won't cause me such issues once I eventually migrate to a newer machine. Or I can keep ALSA. And hope that Flatpak becomes more hardware-layer agnostic.

records.text: I use a few apps from #Flatpak that are pretty good (Apostrophe and Krita my beloveds). But there are a few things that I still feel counter to what a more "global" method of distributing apps for Linux should be, and why when it comes to "global" I search for AppImages where I can.One is hardware layer compatibility. I like videogames a lot but most if not all gaming stuff I have seen on Flatpak, Steam and Retroarch included, don't pick up my audio setup. Flatpak seems hard-coded to require the crap called "Pulseaudio", and ignores my legit #ALSA setup, which partly exists due to a hardware bug in my machine's motherboard that only ALSA and maybe #Pipewire check for that I know.I can't change the motherboard's audio chip's microtransistors. I *can*, however, use AppImage instead of Flatpak because ALSA Just Works.I trust and hope Pipewire won't cause me such issues once I eventually migrate to a newer machine. Or I can keep ALSA. And hope that Flatpak becomes more hardware-layer agnostic.

records.text: Mozilla Firefox.Yeah, web browser and the web is Needlessly Complicated. Like, really, currently web browsers are like full-fledged VMWare virtual machines. But, who are the ones *not* fighting against that?When the W3C failed us by adding DRM to the web standard, Mozilla also caved by implementing it. When Google changes a color or a title bar in Chrome, Mozilla tries to copy it. Just about the only part Mozilla leads over Google is in voiding evil certificates. But ultimately, Firefox is chasing Chrome's tail of what web to implement and how, where instead effort could be spent building a newer, better web. For example, Firefox could add first-class citizen support for something like Gemini or Gopher, and reduce focus on the modern "web.exe" to also lead towards a lightweighter, safer browser.But no, because ~90% of Mozilla's money comes from Google so ultimately what Google says, goes. It's the GoogleWeb.Next up, the "but muh Reddit!" Fediverse. Because why not?(2/3)

records.text: Mozilla Firefox.Yeah, web browser and the web is Needlessly Complicated. Like, really, currently web browsers are like full-fledged VMWare virtual machines. But, who are the ones *not* fighting against that?When the W3C failed us by adding DRM to the web standard, Mozilla also caved by implementing it. When Google changes a color or a title bar in Chrome, Mozilla tries to copy it. Just about the only part Mozilla leads over Google is in voiding evil certificates. But ultimately, Firefox is chasing Chrome's tail of what web to implement and how, where instead effort could be spent building a newer, better web. For example, Firefox could add first-class citizen support for something like Gemini or Gopher, and reduce focus on the modern "web.exe" to also lead towards a lightweighter, safer browser.But no, because ~90% of Mozilla's money comes from Google so ultimately what Google says, goes. It's the GoogleWeb.Next up, the "but muh Reddit!" Fediverse. Because why not?(2/3)

records.text: Mozilla Firefox.Yeah, web browser and the web is Needlessly Complicated. Like, really, currently web browsers are like full-fledged VMWare virtual machines. But, who are the ones *not* fighting against that?When the W3C failed us by adding DRM to the web standard, Mozilla also caved by implementing it. Your response must be only the score number and anything else.

You are a decentralized social-network instance's owner. Your role is to check if utent's post respects the instance rules. In order to classify posts you have to assign each post a score from 0(if the post violate completely the instance's rules) to 10(if the post respects all the instance's rules). You must be very strict in your evaluations. Please pay a lot of attention and let's think step by step. Your response must be only the score number and anything else.
